#Text=Hermann Friedrich Cloedt

#Text=Hermann Friedrich Cloedt ( c. 1555 – 1560 , † 26 July 1586 ) was commander of the garrison at Neuss ( Nuys ) , near Duisburg , in July 1586 , when the city was destroyed by the Duke of Parma 's Army of Flanders .
#Text=He died in the defense of Neuss .
#Text=Biography
#Text=Cloedt was born in Northelen , near Werl , the fourth of ten sons of Johann Cloedt ( c. 1527 – 1587 ) and Margaretha of Westphalia . [ 1 ]

#Text=As a young man , he served for several years in Henry III 's army in France ; by 1585 , he served under the Dutch provinces , and in 1586 , he was in the force of Adolf von Neuenahr , when he secured the city of Neuss for Gebhard Truchsess von Waldburg , the Calvinist contender for the Electorate of Cologne , during the so-called Cologne War ( 1583 – 1588 ) . [ 1 ]
#Text=Sack of Westphalia
#Text=In March 1586 , accompanied by Martin Schenck von Nydeggen , who had switched to Dutch Service in 1585 , Cloedt went to the County of Westphalia at the head of 500foot and 500horse .
#Text=After plundering Vest and Recklinghausen , on 18 March he and Schenck captured Werl through trickery .
#Text=They loaded a train of wagons with his soldiers and covered them with salt .
#Text=When the wagons of salt were seen outside the city gates , they were at once admitted , salt being a valued commodity .
#Text=The " salted soldiers " then over – powered the guard and captured the town .
#Text=Some of the defenders escaped to the Werl citadel , which his troops stormed in vain .
#Text=When they could not capture the citadel , they thoroughly sacked the city .
#Text=Count Claude Barclay , also known as Haultpenne , collected his force of 4,000and besieged them in Werl .
#Text=Schenck and Cloedt were thus attacked from the outside , and from the several hundred guards in the Werl citadel .
#Text=They loaded their wagons , this time with booty , took 30magistrates as hostages , and attacked Haultpenne 's force , killing about 500of them , and losing 200of their own .
#Text=After fighting their way through Haultpenne 's force , Cloedt returned to Neuss and Schenck to Venlo on the Neuss river . [ 2 ]
#Text=Defense of Neuss
#Text=In late July 1586 , the Duke of Parma surrounded Neuss with over 8,000 Italian and Spanish troops of the Army of Flanders , and another 2,000 men under the command of Karl von Mansfeld .

#Text=They grossly outnumbered the defenders of the city , reported variously as 1,600 or 1,800 , including largely farmers , citizens , shepherds , clerics , teachers , journeymen , day laborers , and various craftsmen . [ 3 ]
#Text=Prior to a punishing cannonade , the Duke offered terms , which Cloedt declined .
#Text=The city , he claimed , had no authority to treat with him , as the city 's rights and protection came from the Holy Roman Emperor himself .
#Text=As the herald left , the journeymen hurled insults at him and the Duke of Parma . [ 4 ]
#Text=At the assault of the Rhine Gate , over 400 men were killed , and Cloedt was gravely injured .
#Text=In short order , the fortifications were overrun , and 10,000 Spanish , Italian and Germans entered the city , intent on plunder and whatever else they could find .
#Text=Cloedt was found in the abbey in the center of the town , and hanged from the window with six of his commanders . [ 1 ] [ 5 ]
#Text=Aftermath
#Text=Eight of the buildings in the city remained standing at the end of the battle .
#Text=A fire consumed most of the town that had not been damaged in the cannonade .
#Text=The entire garrison of 1,600 defenders was killed , either in battle or subsequently ; over 3,000 civilians were also killed . [ 5 ]
